newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hectic Budapest sees limit rises in most grains.
newsitem.headline: Hectic Budapest sees limit rises in most grains.

text.p: Price rises in Chicago triggered limit rises in all grains except maize on the Budapest Commodity Exchange (BCE) on Monday, traders said.
"Milling wheat prices rose 20 cents per bushel overnight, a limit-up rise was imminent, it was just a question of who would start it in the local market," said Istvan Markus of Swap.
Milling wheat prices rose the daily 400 forint-limit, with old crop ending at 25,730 forints per tonne for May while new (1997) crop prices ended between 22,200 forints for July and 25,400 for March.
"Those who could not buy milling wheat went for feed wheat," Markus added.
New crop feed wheat prices also rose by the limit to between 21,200 forints for July and 22,600 for December. Untraded May feed wheat remained flat at 22,950 forints.
"The milling wheat price surge was mirrored by feed barley prices as well, a traditional phenomenon of the Budapest market," Markus said.
New crop feed barley prices went limit-up at between 19,000 forints for July and 20,800 forints for December.
Tradeless sunflowerseed futures also rose the limit in all maturities, closing at 34,600 forints for May, 43,550 forints for September and 44,100 for April 1998.
Markus said that whatever the international trends, milling wheat prices would shortly hit a psychological ceiling and a strong downward correction would follow, probably this week.
"One or two further limit-up rises are possible," he said.
Only maize bucked the trend on Monday with the most active May maturity easing 50 forints to 18,450 on position-closing. Other months were mostly flat and untraded except for July with 70 contracts.
Total grains turnover surged to 478.2 million forints or 1,095 contracts from Friday's 234.6 million forints.
Milling wheat accounted for the bulk of the turnover with 770 contracts.
